text: today on x cast the scene in cairo a day
ahead of what are expected to be the
biggest protests yet while covering the
protests in egypt al Jazeera has become
part of the story today six out Jazeera
reporters were arrested briefly
entertained and columnist Nicholas
Kristof reflects on the difficult
position for the army in a People's
Movement says anthony shadid for the new
york times in cairo President Hosni
Mubarak announced a shuffle of his
cabinet today he got rid of the Interior
Minister a figure whose loathed by many
the protesters in liberation square but
he kept key portfolios the same that
shuffle is almost certain to not meet
the demands of protesters in liberation
square the crowds there grew from a few
hundred before dawn to tens of thousands
by dusk those people like the people
behind us here in him Baba defying a
curfew that it keeps getting moved up by
the government for the seventh day the
numbers were huge in liberation square
where there is an almost carnival
atmosphere among the protesters it was a
very different scene in other parts of
Cairo where there's still a lot of
anxiety apprehension and uncertainty
about what's ahead been driving around
central Cairo today and for the most
part today we've seen that it's the army
that's guarding major institutions large
squares wide boulevards in the pyramid
neighborhood there are a number of
armored personnel carriers tanks because
it's been a quite a bit of looting right
behind me the army has captured a man
they say is a de skippy from a jail they
bound him they've laid him down on top
of the tank and they're ready to take
him away back to custody it is at least
a sign that security forces are trying
to reimpose some sort of order in this
city whether they're successful or not
whether it lasts or not is another
matter entirely this is stephen farah
for the new york times in giza brian
Stelter looks at the role of al jazeera
in covering the protests as the uprising
in Egypt nears its second week a lot of
people are calling this al Jazeera's
moment the qatar-based broadcaster has
been showing us pictures that most
American networks haven't been able to
get and they're also having a harder
time getting access because they're so
influential today six Al Jazeera
reporters were arrested briefly
entertained they were released but a lot
of their equipment was seized just the
latest indication of a struggle that
this networks had with the Egyptian
authorities to stay on the air for many
years al Jazeera was viewed with a lot
of skepticism in the US the Bush
administration frequently criticized it
especially during the Iraq war now al
Jazeera also has an english-language
channel and a lot of people don't know
it because it's very hard to access in
the United States it's al Jazeera
English it's been on the air for a few
years most of us can't watch it in the
United States unless we watch on our
computers and now Jazeera told me on
friday that there were 200 times the
normal amount of traffic to their web
stream in that primary day of protests
on Friday three days after the January
25th uprising sorry just looking at
these pictures show d they just it's
chaos but there are protests basically
on the internet by americans saying I
should go to watch us on TV on Comcast
or directv or Time Warner Cable so far
none of those cable companies have
gotten back to me when I've asked them
if they're considering providing access
al Jazeera English this channel has
sprung to life because they were in
Cairo earlier than the US networks and
they've been there in a deeper way with
more reporters and closer up coverage as
the protests in Egypt continue and as
the Middle East becomes a center of
attention for Americans I would think
they'll continue to be calls for better
access to Al Jazeera on TV saying it's
not just good enough to watch it online
we should also be able to watch it on
our couches or in our living rooms
and columnist Nicholas Kristof studied
in Cairo in the early 1980s rhetoric old
house I've been walking around Tahrir
Square and the neighborhood right next
with Bobby loot where I used to live
years ago and I can't tell you how
extraordinary it is to see masses of
people protesting for more democracy
demanding that Mubarak stepped down the
people out at Tahrir are just convinced
that the Army is with them you know they
say we love the army the army loves us
in a strange way that reminds me a
little bit of Tiananmen after martial
law was declared but before the troops
actually opened fire in it at that point
they thought wow you know the the troops
the People's Army will never open fire
on two people and in fact sometimes they
do the Army historically has been very
very close to Mubarak they're all part
of the same elite but the Army has also
been very reluctant to crack down on
people and in fact they essentially
defied an order by Sadat to militarily
put down bread riots in this case feels
to me as if the only way berberich is
going to possibly be able to stay in
power is if he does order a violent
crackdown and if the army obeys I think
neither one is inevitable but I fear
that both are possible maybe the other
thing that leaves me with a little bit
of disquiet as an American is that there
are people who were so excited about
democracy coming to their country and
yet they see the United States and still
sitting on the fence and fundamentally
is still on supporting Mubarak so at the
end of the day they feel inspired by
Tunisia and stymied by America it feels
as if we should be their natural ally
and right now we're not
you
